slide.title: Session 4. Case 1 Acute cholecystitis
slide.notes: Good afternoon. Thanks for the kind introduction. Let me start my case presentation.
slide.notesNormalized: good afternoon. thanks for the kind introduction. let me start my case presentation.
slide.notesHtml:
Good afternoon.

Thanks for the kind introduction.

Let me start my case presentation.
slide.text: Seong-Hun Kim Department of Internal Medicine, Chonbuk National University Hospital and Medical School Jeonju, Korea Session 4. Case 1 Acute cholecystitis

slide.title: Case presentation
slide.notes: An 80-year-old male was transferred to our tertiary hospital after abdominal CT scan due to abdominal pain on the right upper quadrant and epigastric area. The patient underwent subtotal gastrectomy for gastric cancer, was taking medication for hypothyroidism, and blinded for macular degeneration. Family History was unremarkable.
slide.notesNormalized: an 80-year-old male was transferred to our tertiary hospital after abdominal ct scan due to abdominal pain on the right upper quadrant and epigastric area. the patient underwent subtotal gastrectomy for gastric cancer, was taking medication for hypothyroidism, and blinded for macular degeneration. family history was unremarkable.
slide.notesHtml:
An 80-year-old male was transferred to our tertiary hospital after abdominal CT scan due to abdominal pain on the right upper quadrant and epigastric area.

The patient underwent subtotal gastrectomy for gastric cancer, was taking medication for hypothyroidism, and blinded for macular degeneration.

Family History was unremarkable.
slide.text: Case presentation A/S: 80-year-old male C/C: Abdominal pain on the right upper quadrant and epigastric area Present Illness: The patient was transferred to our tertiary hospital after abdominal CT scan due to abdominal pain. Past History: The patient underwent subtotal gastrectomy 15 years ago for gastric cancer, was taking medication for hypothyroidism 1 year ago, and blinded for macular degeneration 1 year ago. Family History: unremarkable

Physical Examination: The patient's pain score was NRS 6. The patient had deep tenderness, rebound tenderness on the Right upper quadrant. Murphy sign was positive Vital signs: BP (90/70 mmHg), HR (95/min), RR (17/min), Body temperature (38.5℃) Laboratory Findings: WBC 18,120 /μl, Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dl, PLT 91,000/μl PT 13.7 sec (9.2-12.6), PT 71% (79-120), PT INR 1.29 (0.88-1.19), aPTT 31.8 (24.8-36.1) ALP 206 IU/L (45-129), GGT 214 IU/L (8-48), AST 161 IU/L, ALT 173 IU/L, T-bilirubin 3.08 mg/dL, hs-CRP 150 mg/dL (0-5) Amylase 71 IU/L (54-168), Lipase 47 U/L (13-60) CEA 3.86 ng/mL (<5.0), CA19-9 30.7 U/mL (<37)

slide.title: Abdominal CT (HD#1) at another clinic
slide.notes: An abdominal CT scan showed distend Gallbladder and Pericholecystic fluid. We also can observe dilated CBD. However definite CBD stone was not noted.
slide.notesNormalized: an abdominal ct scan showed distend gallbladder and pericholecystic fluid. we also can observe dilated cbd. however definite cbd stone was not noted.
slide.notesHtml: An abdominal CT scan showed distend Gallbladder and Pericholecystic fluid. We also can observe dilated CBD. However definite CBD stone was not noted.

slide.title: Q1. What should we do next?
slide.titleNormalized: q1. what should we do next?
slide.notes: His diagnosis is Severe acute cholecystitis with perforation, peri-cholecystic fluid, and cholangitis. His condition was not good for emergent cholecystectomy. And then we thought the endoscopic procedure was not suitable at that time.
slide.notesNormalized: his diagnosis is severe acute cholecystitis with perforation, peri-cholecystic fluid, and cholangitis. his condition was not good for emergent cholecystectomy. and then we thought the endoscopic procedure was not suitable at that time.
slide.notesHtml:
His diagnosis is Severe acute cholecystitis with perforation, peri-cholecystic fluid, and cholangitis.

His condition was not good for emergent cholecystectomy. And then we thought the endoscopic procedure was not suitable at that time.
slide.text: Q1. What should we do next? 1) Cholecystectomy 2) PTGBD (with/without percutaneous drainage) 3) ERCP with endoscopic transpapillary gallbladder drainage 4) EUS-gallbladder drainage

slide.title: PTGBD (HD#1)
slide.notes: So we performed PTGBD. Fortunately, definite leakage was not observed on the tubogram. When we injected contrast media additionally, the patency of the cystic duct was noted, and the filling defect was noted at distal CBD. It was stone which we didn't notice that at first.
slide.notesNormalized: so we performed ptgbd. fortunately, definite leakage was not observed on the tubogram. when we injected contrast media additionally, the patency of the cystic duct was noted, and the filling defect was noted at distal cbd. it was stone which we didn't notice that at first.
slide.notesHtml:
So we performed PTGBD.

Fortunately, definite leakage was not observed on the tubogram.

When we injected contrast media additionally, the patency of the cystic duct was noted, and the filling defect was noted at distal CBD. It was stone which we didn't notice that at first.

slide.title: HD#1 (after PTGBD) Mental change (drowsy), more lowered BP  Atrial fibrillation, old lacunar infarction
slide.titleNormalized: hd#1 (after ptgbd) mental change (drowsy), more lowered bp  atrial fibrillation, old lacunar infarction
slide.notes: After PTGBD, his mental status was changed to drowsy, and BP was more lowered. Atrial fibrillation was newly detected. Old lacunar infarction was noted, but active infarction was not detected.
slide.notesNormalized: after ptgbd, his mental status was changed to drowsy, and bp was more lowered. atrial fibrillation was newly detected. old lacunar infarction was noted, but active infarction was not detected.
slide.notesHtml: After PTGBD, his mental status was changed to drowsy, and BP was more lowered. Atrial fibrillation was newly detected. Old lacunar infarction was noted, but active infarction was not detected.
slide.text: HD#1 (after PTGBD) Mental change (drowsy), more lowered BP  Atrial fibrillation, old lacunar infarction

slide.title: MRCP T2 (HD#2)
slide.notes: We checked MRCP for the checking of pericholecystic fluid and CBD lesion. We were able to watch the large GB stone, and CBD stone. However pericholecystic fluid was slightly improved.
slide.notesNormalized: we checked mrcp for the checking of pericholecystic fluid and cbd lesion. we were able to watch the large gb stone, and cbd stone. however pericholecystic fluid was slightly improved.
slide.notesHtml:
We checked MRCP for the checking of pericholecystic fluid and CBD lesion.

We were able to watch the large GB stone, and CBD stone. However pericholecystic fluid was slightly improved.

slide.title: Q2. What should we do next?
slide.titleNormalized: q2. what should we do next?
slide.notes: Honestly, I like EUS-GBD more. And most of us are expecting EUS-GBD cases today. However, sometimes ETGBD is more useful.
slide.notesNormalized: honestly, i like eus-gbd more. and most of us are expecting eus-gbd cases today. however, sometimes etgbd is more useful.
slide.notesHtml:
Honestly, I like EUS-GBD more.

And most of us are expecting EUS-GBD cases today.

However, sometimes ETGBD is more useful.
slide.text: Q2. What should we do next? 1) Cholecystectomy 2) Keep PTGBD 3) ERCP with endoscopic transpapillary gallbladder drainage 4) ERCP with EUS-gallbladder drainage 5) Only EUS-gallbladder drainage

slide.title: ERCP (HD#10)
slide.notes: We decided to choice ERCP with endoscopic gallbladder stenting. The reasons were that he has CBD stone, a relatively wide cystic duct in cholecystogram. I was concerned about the lack of space for the stent in the gallbladder.
slide.notesNormalized: we decided to choice ercp with endoscopic gallbladder stenting. the reasons were that he has cbd stone, a relatively wide cystic duct in cholecystogram. i was concerned about the lack of space for the stent in the gallbladder.
slide.notesHtml:
We decided to choice ERCP with endoscopic gallbladder stenting. The reasons were that he has CBD stone, a relatively wide cystic duct in cholecystogram.

I was concerned about the lack of space for the stent in the gallbladder.

slide.title: Cholecystogram by PTGBD (on 17th days after ETGBD)
slide.titleNormalized: cholecystogram by ptgbd (on 17th days after etgbd)
slide.notes: On 17th days after ETGBD, cholecystogram showed good function of a plastic stent.
slide.notesNormalized: on 17th days after etgbd, cholecystogram showed good function of a plastic stent.
slide.notesHtml: On 17th days after ETGBD, cholecystogram showed good function of a plastic stent.
slide.text: Cholecystogram by PTGBD (on 17th days after ETGBD)

slide.title: Q3. What should we do next?
slide.titleNormalized: q3. what should we do next?
slide.text: Q3. What should we do next? 1) Cholecystectomy 2) Keep PTGBD 3) Remove PTGBD 4) Convert to EUS-gallbladder drainage

slide.title: Removal of PTGBD (at OPD)
slide.notes: We decided to remove the PTGBD. So we clamp the tube of PTGBD for 7days. And then removed the PTGBD. He has beens doing well without the recurrence of cholecystitis for about 1year.
slide.notesNormalized: we decided to remove the ptgbd. so we clamp the tube of ptgbd for 7days. and then removed the ptgbd. he has beens doing well without the recurrence of cholecystitis for about 1year.
slide.notesHtml: We decided to remove the PTGBD. So we clamp the tube of PTGBD for 7days. And then removed the PTGBD. He has beens doing well without the recurrence of cholecystitis for about 1year.
